name: Sampangan
notes: No visible remains. Reported by Bernet Kempers

name: Payak
notes: ancient bathing place

name: Fort Canning 1984
notes: When the British arrived in Singapore in 1819, the hill was known as the Forbidden Hill by the local population because according to legend the palace of their ancestors once stood there. Excavations have been performed there since 1984, starting with several test pits around the Keramat Iskandar Shah.

name: Pulau Saigon 1990
notes: Surface finds were collected in late 1989 and early 1990 from a site on the opposite bank and further up the Singapore River from Fort Canning. No systematic excavation was possible. Most of the finds dated to the colonial period, but a small number of 14th century sherds are intriguing evidence of the extent of settlement at that period.

name: Istana Kampung Glam 2000
notes: The grounds of the palace of the Sultan of Singapore did not yield 14th century artefacts, but rather a rich assortment of artefacts from the 1790s and onwards.

name: Colombo Court 2000
notes:
July-August 2000
Excavations took place as the land was being prepared for construction of the new Supreme Court Building in 2000. The site yielded many 14th century artifacts and is notable for also including Chinese and Vietnamese ceramics from the 1500s, suggesting that a settlement along the Singapore river continued after the court had moved to Melaka.

name: The Singapore Cricket Club
notes:
April 16 to May 2, 2003
The Padang turned out to be rich in 14th century remains. One important find was a layer of white sand underlying the 14th-century stratum, which confirmed an ancient Malay description of ancient Singapore when it was first inhabited. The main activity at the site seems to have been the working of metal, including recycling Chinese copper coins.
citations: https://epress.nus.edu.sg/sitereports/colombo/

name: St. Andrews Cathedral
notes:
September 16, 2003 to April 10, 2004
More than 300,000 artifacts were excavated in this important campaign, held in advance of construction of underground facilities on the grounds of the St Andrew's Cathedral. Several 14th-century Chinese jars were discovered in intact condition, indicating that they had been intentionally buried. Important artifact types from the site which are rare or non-existent at other Temasek-period sites include a stone peg (perhaps a touchstone for assaying gold), carnelian beads, a Sri Lankan coin, an Indian glass bangle similar to one found on Fort Canning, a Yuan dynasty 10-cash coin, a gun flint perhaps used by one of the sepoys in the East India Company in the early 19th century, a 19th-century Thai coin (perhaps brought by Chulalongkorn on the occasion of his famous visit), two sherds of 17th-century Chinese ceramics, a piece of gold wire, a significant amount of Ming dynasty porcelain, and some Vietnamese porcelain.

Read the Site Report
citations: https://epress.nus.edu.sg/sitereports/sta

name: Ft. Canning Spice Garden
notes:
April 7 to May 3, 2010
This excavation, carried out ahead of construction works on Fort Canning, allowed researchers to identify the site as a footpath leading up to the hill. Artifacts recovered were often broken, and may have been rubbish dumped on the downhill side of the footpath. The finds reinforce the hypothesis that Fort Canning was largely abandoned after 1396, whereas sites closer to the Singapore River were occupied for longer.

Read the Site Report

name: Ft Canning Rescue Dig
notes:
September 2 to November 4, 2018
This rescue excavation was carried out in areas to be affected by renovation works in preparation for Singapore's Bicentennial year. Artifact types (earthenware, stoneware, some porcelains) were consistent with other Ft Canning excavations, and did include Sawankhalok and Sukhothai pieces.
citations: https://epress.nus.edu.sg/sitereports/fortcanning

name:
Grogol Village: Majapahit Settlement
in Trowulan
notes: many ceramic sherds, pottery, pebbles, and the remains of building structures show the  characteristics of former Majapahit settlement areas.
citations: Eriawati, Y., & Nugroho, D. (2023, June). Grogol Village: Majapahit Settlement in Trowulan. In 3rd International Conference on Linguistics and Cultural (ICLC 2022) (pp. 495-505). Atlantis Press.

name: Trowulan - Former Capital City of Majapahit Kingdom
type: site of finds of moveable remains (inscription, sculpture)
notes: The Trowulan site is the only city site of the Hindu-Budha classical age in Indonesia that can still be found. The site covers an area of 11 km x 9 km, which includes the Districts of Trowulan and Sooko within the Regency of Mojokerto and the Districts of Mojoagung and Mojowarno under the Jombang Regency.Thousands of artifacts from the Trowulan Site have been discovered and preserved.  Most of these artifacts discovered by experts and those found by the local community are maintained at the Majapahit Information Centre or known as Pusat Informasi Majapahit (PIM)
citations: https://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5466/  and Wahyudi, D. Y., & Malasari, N. N. The (Lost) Majapahit Heritage: Brick Industry versus Trowulan Cultural Heritage1.

name: Sanggrahan temple
locationNotes: also known as Cungkup Temple, is situated in Sanggrahan Village, Tulungagung Regency, East Java
notes: Historians believe that Sanggrahan Temple was constructed as a resting place for an ash transporting group. The group transported the ashes of Gayatri, a royal Buddhist priestess from the Majapahit period. It is estimated that Sanggrahan Temple was built around 1359-1389 AD, during the reign of King Hayam Wuruk in the Majapahit era. Sanggrahan Temple has been designated as a Cultural Heritage site with the Decree of Tulungagung Regent, issued in 2019 under Number 188.45/96/013/2019
citations: Bioresita, F., Hidayat, H., Kurniawan, J. R., Purnomo, S., & Grussenmeyer, P. (2023, December). 3D Modelling of Sanggrahan Temple Using UAV Imagery and Terrestrial Photogrammetry Method. In IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science (Vol. 1276, No. 1, p. 012043). IOP Publishing.

name: Bontosikuyu Shipwreck Site
locationNotes: exact location is kept private to protect the site
notes: Based on the radiocarbon dating results obtained from the bamboo, and the presence of Chinese ceramics and coins on the site, it is hypothesised that the Bontosikuyu shipwreck was a trading vessel that sailed from China, which sank off Selayar Island during the late 13th to early 14th century. The large quantity of Chinese ceramics found at the site indicate that they were the primary cargo on board the vessel. Celadon wares.
citations: Adhityatama, S., Anderson, R., Abbas, A., King, C. M., Ng, J. C. M., & Orillaneda, B. (2024). A Preliminary Report on the Late 13th-to Early 14th-Century Bontosikuyu Shipwreck Site, Selayar Island, South Sulawesi, Indonesia: A Case Study for Regional Capacity Building and Research. International Journal of Nautical Archaeology, 1-16.

name: Pontada, Lake Motano
locationNotes:
Its topographic coordinates are
2°300
50.72600S,121°200
43.46400E. 
It is located about 150 m off the coast of Lake Matano and covers a 2.2 ha area (Fig. 6). Its depth ranges 3–14m below the surface of the lake, where vertical visibility is about 8–10 m. This made it very easy for the research team to see the archaeological remains during their work.
notes: The fourteenth to early fifteenth century dates for Pontada coincide with a time when Indonesia was experiencing major economic and political developments, notably the emergence of the Majapahit Empire in Java. Interestingly, Muljana (2006:213) interprets the eleventh stanza of the fourteenth century Nāgarakrtāgama epic poem as telling of a journey made by King Hayam Wuruk of Majapahit to Luwu or Matano. The basis for such a trip would have been to trade in pamor luwu, which was being imported to Majapahit Java from coastal Luwu, notably for the manufacture of kris daggers (Do 2013; Reid 1988:110; Solyom and Solyom 1978). Additional evidence of the presence of Javanese from Majapahit in Luwu is seen in the fourteenth to fifteenth century coastal capital of Malangke, which includes a mounded site called Tampung Jawa (meaning Javanese burial ground). The mound contains the oldest clay bricks in South Sulawesi, which may reflect Majapahit technological influence in the region (Bulbeck and Caldwell 2000; Hakim 2000). Such archaeological evidence for Majapahit Javanese presence in coastal Luwu opens the possibility that Javanese blacksmiths migrated to Lake Matano, where they could have passed on their knowledge to local inhabitants. A Javanese connection is further suggested by the kendi with lateral spouts found at Lake Matano; the suspected loom spools also point to an exogenous influence.
citations: ADHITYATAMA, S., YURNALDI, D., WAHYUDIONO, J., RAMADHAN, A. S., DHONY, M. D. K., ABBAS, A., ... & BULBECK, D. (2023). The Mid-Second Millennium AD Submerged Iron Production Village of Pontada in Lake Matano, South Sulawesi, Indonesia. Asian Perspectives.

name: The interior of the Majapahit royal palace
locationNotes: This according to the identification of Gomperts, Haag, Carey and Umbaran
notes: While pavilions further to the north would have been the site of audiences with outsiders, and certain royal ceremonies, the remains here are most likely of structures of the private areas of the royal palace compounds, as described in the Nagarakrtagama. This is the Kĕḍaton area of the East Javanese town of Trowulan.
citations:
Gomperts, A., Haag, A., Carey, P., & Umbaran, D. (2014). Archaeological Identification of the Majapahit Royal Palace: Prapañca’s 1365 Description Projected onto Satellite Imagery. The Journal of the Siam Society, 102, 67-118. The most relevant excavation report is Arifin, Karina, and R. Cecep Eka Permana (eds.). [2011]. Laporan Penelitian Arkeologi Terpadu Indonesia I (PATI-I 2008). Depok: Fakultas Ilmu Pengetahuan
Budaya, Universitas Indonesia/Orchid Media Creasindo

name: Audience Pavilions of the Majapahit Royal Palace
locationNotes: Reconstructing the old plan of the royal capital of Majapahit involves reconciling the descriptions found in Prapanca's Negarakrtagama and other kakawin, with surveys and archaeological excavations. Given the intense changes in the landscape brought with the Dutch introduction of sugar cultivation to the area (and the usefulness of Majapahit-era bricks for warehouses and factory buildings), much uncertainty remains, despite the richness of the site.
notes: The royal palace as described by Prapanca includes a number of pavilions for receiving visitors, likely in the northern portion of the palace compound. Private quarters were likely to the south, in the Candi Kedaton area. Many areas here have been excavated but full reports are hard to access. The 2008 dates here refers to the cited survey by Gomperts, Haag and Carey.
citations: GOMPERTS, AMRIT, ARNOUD HAAG, and PETER CAREY. “Stutterheim’s Enigma: The Mystery of His Mapping of the Majapahit Kraton at Trowulan in 1941.” Bijdragen Tot de Taal-, Land- En Volkenkunde 164, no. 4 (2008): 411–30. http://www.jstor.org/stable/27868517.
compilersNotes: For Majapahit city, let's just include this area (now the Museum), candi kedaton, and perhaps the city gates?

name: Phanom Surin wreck
notes: carried aromatic wood, ivory tusk, deer antlers, Chinese stoneware, Gulf turquoise glazed ware, and Gulf torpedo jars (one with an inscribed personal name). Recent analyses of the bitumen lining in the Phanom Surin torpedo jars (Connan et al. 2020) demonstrate two distinct Iranian bitumen sources and two types of torpedo jars. The Phanom Surin vessel was built in a sewn-plank Arab–Persian Gulf tradition (Guy 2017)
citations:
Horton M, Boivin N, Crowther A. 2020. Eastern Africa and the early Indian Ocean: understanding mobility in a globalising world. J. Egypt. Hist. 13:1/2380–408

Guy J. 2017. The Phanom Surin shipwreck, a Pahlavi inscription, and their significance for the early history of lower central Thailand. J. Siam Soc. 105:179–96[Google Scholar]

name: Belitung ship wreck
notes: also a sewn-plank boat in the Gulf tradition; the vessel included one timber native to Africa
citations: Flecker M. 2001. A ninth-century ad Arab or Indian shipwreck in Indonesia: first evidence for direct trade with China. World Archaeol. 32:3335–54[Google Scholar]

name: Cirebon wreck
notes: The post–969 ce Cirebon wreck (Indonesia) was built in local Southeast Asian style and, along with Chinese wares, carried Middle Eastern glass; unworked lapis from Afghanistan; and rock crystal, possibly from the Middle East, South Asia, or Madagascar in East Africa (Liebner 2014).
citations: Liebner HH. 2014. The siren of Cirebon: a tenth century trading vessel lost in the Java Sea PhD Thesis Univ. Leeds Leeds, UK:

name: Sungai Jaong
locationNotes:
Date précise de l’opération : 9‑11 mai 2018, 19‑30 juillet 2018, 12 juin-10 juillet 2019, 20 septembre-26 octobre 2022
1.7172300317396163, 110.34497242657612
notes: Radiocarbon dates obtained on five of these floors place metallurgical activities at Sungai Jaong between the 10th and 13th centuries, but the presumed oldest floors at the foot of the hillock remain to be dated. Tons of iron ore slag have been recovered from this area, which was also subject to excavations by Tom Harrisson in the 1950s and 60s.

Sherman bin Sauffi, Stéphanie Leroy et Yohan Chabot, « Archaeological Investigations at Sungai Jaong (2018, 2019, 2022), Sarawak, Malaysia » [notice archéologique], Bulletin archéologique des Écoles françaises à l’étranger [En ligne], Asie du Sud-Est péninsulaire et insulaire, mis en ligne le 13 septembre 2023, consulté le 06 août 2024. name: Pasir Kapal inscription
type: site of finds of moveable remains (inscription, sculpture)
notes: The Pasir Kapal Inscription provides direct evidence for reconstructing the scenario of the Mongol invasion to Java. The inscription is a useful supplement to the surviving Chinese historical records, specifically in terms of the scale of the fleet, the navigation routes, and the dates of events. The inscription supports a conclusion that the 500 ships departed from Quanzhou on January 22, CE 1293, and then traveled through the Sea of Seven Islands, the Paracel Islands, coastal central-southern Vietnam, and the islands of Catwick, Hon Hai, Con Son, Natuna, Tambelan, Serutu (and also probably Karimata), and Pulau Gelam. Thereafter, the fleet reached Karimun Jawa Island, landing at Tuban in northeastern Java to begin the battle on March 22, CE 1293.
citations:
The research potential of archaeology in Maya-Karimata Islands (Potensi Arkeologi di kepulauan Maya-Karimata)
Archaeological Research News - Archaeological Center of South Kalimantan (Berita Penelitian Arkeologi-Balai Arkeologi Kalimantan Selatan), 11 (2017), pp. 1-39
(in Bahasa)

name: Candi Jawi
notes: a syncretic Hindu-Buddhist candi (temple) dated from the late 13th century Singhasari kingdom. The Nagarakretagama canto 56 mentioned this temple as Jajawa. King Kertanegara of Singhasari ordered the construction of this temple to provide a place of worship for the adherents of Shiva-Buddha sect, a syncretic religion patronage by the king.

name: The Temasek Wreck
notes: This shipwreck site was excavated by the Archaeology Unit of the ISEAS – Yusof Ishak Institute, on behalf of Singapore's National Heritage Board, in stages over three years starting in 2016. The work resulted in the recovery of approximately 4.4 tonnes of ceramics and a few other objects. None of the ship's structure survived. Based mostly on their interpretation of the blue-and-white porcelains recovered, excavators date the wreck to between 1340 and 1371 CE, and posit that its destination was the port of Temasek (Singapore).
citations: See https://epress.nus.edu.sg/sitereports/temasekwreck and  https://www.iseas.edu.sg/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Flecker_TWPS04_Final_r.pdf

name: Empress Place 2015
notes: This was a large-scale rescue excavation by the ISEAS Archaeology unit, with funding and support from the National Heritage Board (NHB), the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), the Ministry of National Development, and private donors. Despite the compromised nature of the excavation, many ceramics were recovered, as well as intriguing evidence of port activities.
citations: Aaron Kao, The Archaeology of the Empress Place Site, Singapore (2015), NUS Press Site Reports, See https://doi.org/10.56159/sitereport12

name: No 1 Shipwreck off Hainan
notes: While the scientific report has not yet been published, press statements from the National Cultural Heritage Administration of China report that a total of 890 pieces of relics were excavated from the No. 1 shipwreck, including porcelain and pottery items, as well as copper coins. The wreck lies at a depth of 1500 metres and was discovered by the crew of a manned submersible. According to the South China Morning Post, the two sites were jointly investigated by the National Centre for Archaeology, the Chinese Academy of Science, and a local museum in Hainan using both manned and unmanned submersible
citations: https://english.www.gov.cn/news/202406/13/content_WS666af4fcc6d0868f4e8e814b.html
